I give my all to this job because of the families and how much difference you can make. It's so encouraging and I look forward to going in to work! Great trainings and very organized as a whole.
cons: Sadly, the coworkers. Most are good but there's too much gossip and cattiness at times. A lot of techs roll their eyes when you ask them to do stuff especially if you're younger than them. Also, pay rates are much lower than other hospitals, especially if they hire you as a new grad. Yearly raises will never catch you up to coworkers who come in with even just a few years of experience and start at a higher rate.

review_title: Major potential harmed by leader disfunction
pros: Wonderful mission! They really do care about the kids and will always do the right thing for patients and their families. The happiest employees are the ones closest to the mission. Benefits are good and they have a growth plan in addition to a share plan. Holidays and vacation time is average if not generous. Most managers and directors are easy/great to work with.
cons: Upper leadership is toxic (especially in administration/hr). Micromanagement seems to be the name of the game up there, and it shows. The company is weak in the leadership area because VPs and above aren't working as leaders, they are working as worker bees. Stress and urgent needs are put ahead of planned priorities, and often this stress roles downhill to lower level employees. Lost several high performing, high level leaders recently.

pros: Very collaborative environment.  The majority of the people are great to work with, and you will enjoy coming to work every day.  They host very fun and engaging employee events and give t-shirts and gifts to the employees regularly.  There is a huge, ongoing effort to develop and promote employees in clinical jobs.
cons: There are no efforts to hire or promote minorities; thus, there are very few in management or leader positions.  All efforts for talent management, planning, and succession are for managers and above.  There is are no flexible work schedules, and no work-life balance in most areas.  All efforts for developing and promoting employees are focused on the clinical jobs.

review_title: Children's has a great mission but poor leadership that treats its employees as commodities
pros:
- Great mission, it always felt good to go to work knowing you were helping kids
- You get to work with smart people who are very dedicated to what they do
- Well funded organization
cons:
- Leadership manages as if every issue is a burning platform issue.
- Tullie is not connected to clinical operations, leading to many poor decisions and/or unending meetings with no resolutions to the problems at hand.
- Leadership doesn't value their people unless you have worked there for a long time.  They have a very well established "good ol girls" network.  
- If you do end up working here treat this as a 2-3 year job then move on to your next career goal because you most likely won't move up within this organization or you will burn out.

review_title: If you can find intrinsic rewards in your work and don't require sincere validation, come on in!
pros: Taking care of kids, working with great clinical and non-clinical staff.
cons: Management only cares about their bottom line.  No regard for good employees, or long time employees.  If you leave with your 10+ years of experience, that just means we can hire someone with no experience, cheaper.  Decisions are made by people who have not taken care of an actual patient in years without any input from those at the bedside, doing the real work. Stop cooking the books regarding the outrageous turnover and find out why so many people leave, constantly.  Does no one in HR notice that you're posting jobs for the same department every week?  Shouldn't that be a clue?

job_title: in Executive Park Post Office, GA
pros: Care for kids is best in Georgia.  Training department does a good job.  Great benefits package.  Well-financed organization.  Foundation is very successful.
cons: Administrative division exists in a world of its own with at least one long term department head who is not qualified for their role.  Vendors are considered based on relation to officers, tickets from advertisers are accepted by VPs while employees are not allowed to use them because it is against the rules and everything is evaluated as a sound bite.  The board is snowed on a regular basis.  Winning Best Place to Work and Strong4Life are given greater importance than anything else while market research methodology and results that should inform business direction are ignored or altered to make it appear as if management has made good decisions.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros:
Various locations are convenient from any area of metro Atlanta

Your contribution indirectly or directly affects the well-being of children

Free parking
cons:
Negative, stressful working environment

Inflexible work/life balance; every minute of your work day is monitored

Clinical staff and employees are treated poorly

Micromanaging is damaging to morale and productivity

pros:
Company Mission
PTO is generous
new office building for support staff
Concierge
cons:
Absolutely no work from home due to lack of trust from leadership. 
some of top leadership is very cliquish
Promotions based on popularity verses competency in some areas
Recent furloughs and job eliminations
Lack of transparent communications from leadership

Limited authority or decision making below VP level. Once again, this is a leadership control and trust issue.

pros: Mission-driven organization that makes a true positive impact on the community. Great benefits.
cons: While the organization has enjoyed numerous years of being recognized nationally as a top employer, it has primarily been based on feedback from clinical employees and at the expense of non-clinical professionals. The Administrative Division in particular is a huge area of concern as leadership, specifically the Chief Administrative Officer, is completely out of touch with current marketplace trends and refuses to engage and listen to employees within the division. This individual uses her position only for her own personal gain, and as an employment vehicle for her personal friends.

pros: Good benefits; which is the only reason I work here. I have a great manager that is open to new ideas and is always looking for improvements.
cons: HR has ignored the fact that interpreters/translators salaries are below the market. We have never heard directly from HR. It will be nice to have someone from HR come to a staff meeting and acknowledge us. This issue is supposedly under investigation but we have not heard anything about it for almost a year now. It does not take a long time to figure out that the interpreters at the hospital across the street make more money that we do. I hope HR also takes into account that we are NOT only interpreters but we have to translate discharge instructions which requires a different skill set and translators are in a higer pay scale than interpreters. We do both for the lowest salary possible which is great for the organization but very unfair to us.

review_title: This organization is clearly deivided into staff and management.  CHOA does not walk the talk.
job_title: Business Operations Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: CHOA offers an excellent benefits package.  If you're in a management position, you are given ample vacation/sick time.
cons: The company culture does not support /promote the growth of staff members.  Staff are viewed as second-class employees.  The maximum annual raise for a staff member is 3 percent.

review_title: Like rats leaving a sinking ship that has no captain
pros: Great mission and great teamwork environment for those with management that are not there for themselves. Opportunity for personal growth is there only if you have been identified as a personal favorite by management who use their roles to make friends and discard all others.
cons: Probably a textbook example of how not to manage. A horrible work environment for those who fall victim to management abuses and bullying behavior. If people complain they only face an even worse situation. I have seen employees treated in a way that I would not treat an animal. The rankings in best employee listings do not reflect the reality of the day to day mistreatment of employees. A culture of sycophancy does not benefit either the best employees or the children who are supposed to be the very purpose of this non-profit organization.

review_title: Good and getting better in IT
pros:
Many of the negative reviews are from team members who were let go because they were not pulling their weight and contributing.  This is a company that values employees - but we are here for a mission and a purpose.  Management is working hard and has improved pay and the working environment.  The new working location is the best I've ever seen for an IT department.

CHOA has a great mission.  I love coming to work and feeling like I am really making a difference!  Turnover is well under 10% and that is good for IT.  People stay for a reason.  Mission and value.
cons: When project deadlines hit, hours can be long sometimes - but this is the same in ANY IT department.  At least we are doing this for a meaningful purpose.. Not to make someone rich.

review_title: Children's knows what it means to care
pros: Open communication from leadership to all levels of organization members helps everyone feel connected and invested. The most unique thing about Children's is the commitment  and dedication to the organization's mission throughout all employee and leadership levels.  While we have to make financially smart decisions, everyone from the CEO to the nurses and doctors to environmental services would say "we're here for the kids". Children's lives by this mantra and makes decisions with integrity and caring.  Also, there are tons of opportunities for professional growth and development.
cons: We are so dedicated to providing the best care possible and to always raising the bar that we can get tired!  No sooner do we reach a pinnacle of achievement than we are climbing the next mountain.

review_title: Lack of Transparency for Provision of Accommodations
pros: World-class patient care, Staff that really love the patients, Great benefits, Top physicians, One of the Best Children's Hospitals, Magnet-status. I was very proud to be a CHOA Nurse, and I hoped to work until retirement.
cons:
Do you have a disability?  Good luck with getting any help with accommodations from CHOA to help in your role as a CHOA employee.. What is the official process for accomodations? I would still be a CHOA nurse if I did not have a disability :-(

Toxic staff are allowed to get away with blatant bullying behavior because they are long-time CHOA employees. This is probably the case in departments with high staff turnover.

pros: An exceptional CEO , Chief Medical Officer and General Counsel are among the strong leaders at Children's navigating through the many challenges faced in healthcare. Beautiful, new, state of the art administrative building with standing desk option for all, individual laptops and opportunity to work inside or outside in spaces away from your desk, and ample free parking. Flexible schedule within reason. Comprehensive benefit package. Dedicated, helpful co-workers.
cons: Currently, no work from home options. Health and wellness activities are offered regularly; however, individual workloads and whether individuals are hourly or salaried may make it hard for some to participate.

pros:
- When I worked in a clinical role, I loved working with kids! Interacting with them was always a joy!

- In the clinical setting, I loved my coworkers and teamwork among nurses was great on most units.

- In clinical setting, patient ratios are MUCH better than in the adult world.

- The main pro of working in a support role is that you can come into work early and leave early. You may have to log in at home here and there, but the building is pretty empty after 4pm. It is nice not to be expected to work late
cons:
- Leadership is very out of touch with the challenges and realities of patient care

- Below average pay

- NO work from home flexibility whatsoever, even for those whose entire job can easily be done from home via webex. This is disappointing, especially during a pandemic. Note that leadership recently implemented a TEMPORARY policy where employees can work from home 50% of the time, but there is quite a bit of pressure from management not to choose to work from home 50% of the time.

- No concern for employee health and safety during the pandemic. Clinical staff is working with barely an PPE and recycling PPE more than other local hospitals. In the support areas, there is frequently no soap in the bathrooms, they are still cramming people into conference rooms (despite previously stating all meetings would also be available via webex), hand sanitizer is still difficult to find, and cleaning measures are still as weak as they were prior to the pandemic.

- I have worked in many other corporate settings and have never been as micromanaged as I am here. Leadership is more focused on you being in your seat than they are about productivity, which is in stark contrast to anywhere else I have worked in the past.

- Leadership always says the right things to try to make it seem like they care about employees, but they do not follow through and their actions do not support their words.

- Constant messaging from management is to be grateful for your job. There were many recent layoffs and furloughs which already damaged morale - Why then continue to decrease morale by using them as a threat? I think we all know that if this has to be said, the reality is that your job may not be amazing.

review_title: Intern in the Foundation for Children's Healthcare of Atlanta
pros:
Wonderful group of people

Mangement is eager to teach you the ropes and allows you to be apart of the day to day decisions of the department
Helped me gain the experience I needed to land a great job with another company at the end of the internship.
There were not any jobs available within CHOA when my internship was complete ... However, I was called several months later and told about a new position that had become available... I thought that was really impressive
cons: None really! I wish I could have stayed there.

The organization's mission/vision/values
On-site exercise options

review_title: Believe the hype (the bad reviews that is)
pros: Great mission, we are on all the ‘lists’ for great places to work even though everyone (staff, managers, even directors) joke about this
cons: Lack of care and understanding from executives, they are so out of touch with reality that it’s scary. They make decisions that are negatively impacting their entire teams and have the mentality of ‘if you don’t like it, go somewhere else.’ The hilarious part is asking employees to write a positive review instead of actually working to fix the very broken culture of bias, favoritism, ‘do as I say, not what I do’ mentality, lack of honesty, transparency and human decency. pros: Great place for kids to receive care.
cons:
Antiquated policies and practices.  While most companies encourage remote working options,  CHOA  is building a new facility to ensure their employees are all onsite.  

No growth potential.  If you're not clinical staff, no opportunity for tuition reimbursement or continuous learning opportunities.   

Pay is not competitive.   The culture is "not what you know, but who you know".  Promotions are based on popularity and relationships,  not knowledge or skill sets.

pros: I think senior management is truly committed to "putting the children" first. They walk the walk and talk the talk.
cons: CHOA really tries hard to create and sustain a real strong sense of "teamwork". Unfortunately, at least within the training department, this is at the cost of recognizing and appreciating individual contributions. Going with the flow is rewarded; offering critiques and suggestions for improvement is not. A colleague spoke of an interview in which 80% of the questions dealt with "teamwork", "getting along", "handling difficult co-workers"; she said that, in contrast, less than 20% of the questions addressed clinical /professional competence.

review_title: It used to be a good company with management who cares.
pros: I enjoyed working with all my coworkers the entire hospital. It was great to see the patients they are so cute...and fun to be around. I worked their for over twenty five years I have had great management people who really cared about the employes and their families.
cons: They have the worst attitude towards their injured employees,they harass and bully them far beyond reason. The insurance company (PMA) gives you the run around. They refuse to return your call,and approve the medical services their own doctors in the plan prescribes for you.

job_title: Patient Service Associate in Sandy Springs, GA
pros: I worked for the Scottish Rite location at Children's Healthcare of Atlanta. I really did love my job. They offer benefits, discounts, and there is a great concierge service where you can receive discounted tickets for special events, museums, and other attractions. Very flexible with your schedule.  Company culture is fantastic. Coworkers become like family over time.  Get to work with patients and their families. Babies!!
cons: Can be short staffed, which leads to you feeling possibly overworked. Usually gets busy around flu season. Prone to get sick easily.

review_title: Not as colorful as the seem
pros: I've met some of the greatest people working at CHOA. The newest addition of their expansion project is very nice as well, but is also part of their downfall.
cons:
The potential for growth for non-clinical staff is lackluster. Compensation is okay, but not comparable to the market for certain positions.

CHOA says they care about work-life balance for their employees, but prior and even during COVID-19 they have shown otherwise. After moving to the new Support Center, working from home became a thing of the past...when it's really THE thing of the future, but not at CHOA. This new, pretty building is to promote more collaboration and seems to be more for optics than anything. Then the pandemic happened and we granted the opportunity to work from home, however, there were clear reservations. My team was very effective over the 3-month timeframe as were others, however, some were not which is to be expected. All jobs aren't meant to be remote. Once stay-at-home orders began to be lifted, CHOA wasted no time in thinking through how they could get their employees back in that pretty building. Leadership began phasing in as early as June 1st with staff back in two weeks later. Work from home options yet again ceased and the building is back at 100% capacity (probably not 100%, but that is certainly the intent). Leadership has not requested any feedback from their employees which lets us know they really don't care about how we feel or what we think. They are forcing us to expose ourselves and families to this virus that is more out of control now than it was when we started working from home. This is very disappointing and not like the culture they seem to want to portray.

cons: My downside was my Manager. Very poor management without direction. Only came to me to bail them out of a jam. Never any input. I had to do my own reviews. Had various growing pains and revolving door for Finance VP's which led to inconsistentancies. No growth in the finance area.

review_title: Keep looking. Do not stop here if you're looking for a career.
pros: There are some really nice people, but the morale is so poor, it ultimately ends up being a negative environment. Everyone is looking for another job.
cons: Chaotic, poor management, lack of respect for individuals. Projects that never seem to complete despite months and months of work. Little to no resources provided to get most projects completed despite management promises that projects can happen. Clinical side is clearly vastly different from The Park.

pros: It is a job and we all need them. It is fairly close proximity to my home.

The CEO takes home a nice bonus package at least a quarter million, employees are given a $30.00  gift card to krogers. Most professionals work a 12.5 hr shift, we are only allowed one 30 minute break during this time. We need to be unionised to eliminate unfair work practices.

pros: Children’s is a great place to work. The benefits,flexibility in schedule and the education they provide are excellent.  They also really appreciate their nurses.  Best of all are the patients.
cons: The requirements for your yearly CAN  review to maintain your RN level are the same for part time as full time  makes I’d difficult to participate in meetings if you are not already working that day.  To commute in for a meeting on a day off takes a large portion of your day for a one hour meeting when you have a long commute.

review_title: CHOA is GREAT if you are NOT in IS&T
pros: Knowing that you are working collecitively to positively influence the quality of life for a child is awesome.  Children's is a great place to work as the overall benefits package is very comfortable and company perks are nice. The Company's commitment to physical Wellness is commendable.
cons:
Children's, in particular their IS&T deparment has and still experiences the highest numbers of turnover compared to other Hospitals and most corporate companies.  Employees leave in droves and those who have not are looking or either finishing their education in preparation to leave.

Most of management take inappropriate liberties with subordinates that are unheard of modern day corporate America.  Management, is mostly comprised of non-educated individuals who were given positions of authority based on tenor and not actual qualifications for holding a mangerial position.  You pretty much have a bunch of insecure bullies without degrees who are running rampant in across the organization without any policing.  Any person who presents themselves as a threat (meaning educated or not tolerant of such misconduct) has just placed themselves in the line of fire and will be harrassed until either they leave the company or move into a clinical position or another department.

For fear of employment subordiates accept the beligerant attitude and inappropriate behavior and 'Good Old Boy' network of promoting within divisions. Persons are promoted based on tenor and not competancy. The environment here is definately hostile and lack of  management being qualified for said positions is what permeates such an environment. This is clearly seen a being status quo among IT departments where the managers or supervisors have been with the comapany 7+ years. job_title: One of the IT Departments in Atlanta, GA
pros: This organization does so much for children in the state of Georgia. I was very excited to be a part of CHOA and to be able to take pride in knowing how my work was positively impacting the lives of families. The CEO is fabulous and dynamic.
cons: Mid-level management and director-level management is spotty and weak. The IT department takes a "fly by the seat of your pants" tack. Attempts to change this culture often fall on deaf ears. It felt like an "Epic shop". If you want to do very little, go nowhere and sweet-talk your manager for preferential treatment, this is the area for you. They do not readily promote from within. This may or may not fly in the face of the FLSA. My experience so far has a "bait and switch" feel to it. They do not have many official trainers on staff so you are left holding the bag and as a consequence users train each other over time, sometimes incorrectly. This causes repeated issues with the main EMR application. They do not follow the handbook policy as it relates to making inter-departmental transfers.

review_title: Loved being a part of the impact this organization has on the community
pros: It is unbelievable to be a part of an Organization so committed to kids. Every day I was incredibly  committed to hiring right because the collective people at CHOA truly are dedicated to all better. I worked with an incredibly talented internal team and supported managers and teams that embraced me as their own! I worked with CEO Dr. Talley for a time, and was tremendously impressed with him--he embraced and lived out CHOA's mission, and I believe that his mentality and genuine concern flowed from top down. CHOA was a tremendous experience for me and I am glad I worked there. I thought I would stay and grow and end my career there, but I outgrew the organization. If you are a working mother looking to be successful but find work/life balance and make an impact on the community; if you are clinical; there is no better place to work in my mind!! Likewise, the level of care my former colleagues provide--from the admin to clinical team is unbeatable because employees genuinely care to make a difference! I wouldn't take my children anywhere else! CHOA is also a company that helps you write your ticket-- employers love to see CHOA work experience on your résumé!
cons: Ultimately, I left because of two reasons-- from a non-clinical/professional side, the organization is built out, so the opportunity to grow/develop within different areas of HR ( recruiting/training/HR, etc) (which was there when I started) no longer existed. In reading the previously posted non-clinical reviews--I agree with the majority of them--there is no opportunity for internal growth--unless you are in the sorority of Senior Leadership--then your opportunity-- and your salary/promotional increase is whatever you make it. I also left because toward the end, I didn't  see much autonomy in my manager and director-- it seemed they were given instruction from top down, and I knew that as I grow, I want to personally impact. I am a huge proponent of wellness, but also agree SR leadership took it too far. I also think that because the mission of CHOA is so bold and the community opinion is so high, the organization doesn't do a good job speaking to the challenges of working there--thus setting unrealistic expectations for employees.  The majority of the clinical people I worked with sincerely loved their position, leaders and opportunity, so I do think the  majority of my concerns speak to non-clinical roles-- there is a big disconnect between working at CHOA as a clinical provider and as a professional/non-clinicall. Pay is a challenge, but it's hospital and non-profit--which are two industries known for offering a stronger overall package to compensate for lower pay--and I believe overall CHOA does a good job of building a solid comp & benefits package.

The CEO and CAO are running the corporate side like a dictatorship. They think they are untouchable, I do not blame them because there is no accountability whatsoever. People have been complaining for years for this to change and nothing has. Everyone is afraid to call them out because retaliation is the normal there. Since nobody will stand up for what is right, the directors put so much pressure on their employees to the point of burnout. The employees receive no recognition for their hard work and the directors take all of the credit. It was also kind of difficult to see people in management positions or higher who do not even know what your job description is. 
It is also hard to not take notice that CHOA is still functioning years behind other workplaces. Teleworking is a thing of the past. It would also be better if CHOA was more transparent. I would be willing to bet if they were more truthful about the furloughs, they would have employees rating them higher because they would have felt important enough to be informed. Instead they announced it out of the blue AND told management to lie about what happened to said employees. If employees were truly being let go, the employee was told they cannot talk about it or they would lose their pay. They use bully tactics to put fear in their staff to keep them quiet. Unfortunately they are starting to lose control of their employees because people are finally starting to talk about it. The cry for help is there, they just need someone to step in that can make a difference.

review_title: They only care about money, not employees
pros: Nice gym, training instructors are awesome, otherwise, as a person of color, I have nothing good to say about this company.
cons:
They are not who they portray themselves to be. 

If you are a person of color, there is no room for growth in your career within the office/support center. I cannot speak for the hospital side. 99% of jobs outside of Patient Access lack diversity in a major way. It seems people of color are only hired for Patient Access roles. When you look at VP's, Executives, Upper Management, HR, and anything other than Patient Access, you will see only a dab of diversity. The newly built support building proves this. Just by walking certain floors, you will see 99% of people of color sit on one floor, and walking other floors, you will see 99% are filled with non-people of color and only a small drop of "diversity" if you will. 

When the new support building was put up, they completely took away work from home. Which is essentially going backwards in a time where we can be advancing forward in the world. Choa is having us contribute to the detriment of the environment by making us commute to work when we have the ability to work from home. The stress of Georgia traffic alone is detrimental to your physical and mental health. However, as stated before, this is all about money. They spent a lot of money on the new building so they want us in there using it. There could have been a better plan to build something on a smaller scale that allows us to work from home if we are able. We now have to share cubicle space in this new building and it is very open and distracting. 

During the pandemic they have handled it in the worst way by making us borrow money from the company that we have to pay back in order to meet our 40 hours. They gave us the option to “re-deploy” and work in the hospital but seriously, who wants to put themselves at risk by going to work in the hospital? They are also forcing us to come back to work on 6/29/2020, knowing we cannot social distance due to the fact that we share cubicles. While our competitors have allowed their employees to work from home indefinitely, this speaks volumes on the way Choa operates. They stated in so many words that they do not care about our children & not having access to daycare/summer camps, nor do they care if you have to look after someone who is immunocompromised. As stated, it is all about money. They paid for the building so they want us in there no matter how much it puts us at risk, by any means necessary. With COVID numbers increasing & no medical solution in sight, they want us to risk our lives coming to work when we have the ability to continue to work from home. It’s as if we are being punished for not being able to work in a building they spent money on. 

All in all, this company is money hungry and only cares about the dollar and not the employee. They will sell you a dream of a "career" but keep you stuck in roles that do not allow for any advancement while giving promotions to non-people of color.  Sometimes even your own manager/supervisor will prevent you from growth within the company. They do not care about what is best for their employees, only what benefits them at the expense of the employees who work hard to keep their operations running with little to no reward. They are an illogical thinking company that operates on the basis of, “if it doesn’t make sense, it makes sense.” 

If you are a person of color, beware. If you care about your mental health, beware. If you care about work-life balance, beware. If you are looking for growth and opportunity, this is not the company for you. Best of luck.
